transcription.text: [MUSIC PLAYING]
All right, great.
My name is Nikolai.
I'm here representing Nexus Development.
We're a Ethereum, R&D shop, and consultancy.
And among other things, we publish open source software
to help other developers.
The one I'm going to focus on today
is called DAPL.
So what is DAPL?
DAPL is a developer tool for people targeting
the Ethereum virtual machine.
It's a collection of utilities that are mostly
loosely coupled, but they all center around a common data
model, which is one of our major key innovations,
from my point of view.
So I'll go through all these real quick,
and then I'll go into a little more detail.
The main thing is this shared data model,
which we call the DAPL.
And it's basically a descriptor for both code packages
and also deployed systems.
And then chain forking, creating local chain forks,
and then having modified EVM behavior
on those local chain forks.
These three things together, you do some really interesting
things.
And in particular, the entire development workflow
of creating contract systems that talk to other contract
systems, it helps a lot to have these features.
So let me just go through--
you should use it again.
The first thing is that the key insight that
drives this first innovation is that Ethereum land
is slightly different from most of the other programming
language environment worlds.
Because in Ethereum, we actually all share
a global runtime environment.
And so this blurs the line between something that's
a code package and something that's
an instance or a deployed code object.
So this would be like, if you hard code
like a web endpoint into your JavaScript package or something,
that's considered bad practice.
You want to separately have it depend on a configuration
where there you configure your endpoints
and then have all the logic in your code.
But in Ethereum, you have things like, say, the Ether token
wrapper, which is stateful.
It's a deployed object that you interact with.
But there's absolutely no reason to redeploy.
Everyone should be treating it sort of like a library.
Like you have the math library on Ethereum.
Everyone uses the same address.
Or in theory, we should be doing that.
For the math functions, likewise,
we should all be using the same package
for the Ether token wrapper, which
creates it into an ERC20 token.
But that has an address in it.
That's part of the definition of that code package,
is that there's an object deployed.
So yeah, so this is an example.file.
Don't worry about it too much.
The key thing is this highlighted thing,
which is that the type information is very rich.
It has all the metadata we need to just fully
recreate how this thing got here.
So the next innovation is chain forking.
You'll notice it's a user experience very similar to Git.
That's because they're very similar data structures.
The missing part here is merge because there's
no analog to resolving merge conflicts automatically
when you try to replay a set of transactions.
And it doesn't have the same result.
So that's chain forking.
And finally-- OK, this is an example of basically,
you can actually fork any public Ethereum chain
without their permission, basically,
just because of how the data structure works.
But by default, we let you specify remote one.
And internal just means a brand new blank EVM
on your machine and fork.
The EVM more than should be self-explanatory.
And finally, EVM extensions are when
you slightly change the behavior of the virtual machine
on your private chain.
And this lets you do some really interesting things,
as you'll see.
So now let's go through the workflow.
How we developed apps using double.
First thing, find some dependencies.
This is a habit that you have in every other language.
For some reason, everyone wants to start from scratch
from their creating their own contracts.
This is our-- as a hint, we suggest
that we have something sort of like a standard library, which
we are keen to get formally verified.
And it has a lot of stuff like proxy actors, tokens,
blah, blah.
You can read the list.
I'm sure-- yeah, the idea is that these
are composable building blocks.
Each is very simple and easy to verify.
And then you actually-- most apps
can be built out of just a collection of things.
So each DAP that each new system that we make usually
only has one or two contracts with custom logic.
And then it has five dependent contracts that are just things
we've built before.
So again, if you're interested in formal verification,
this is a-- this-- again, it's very simple contracts,
but they are in production systems right now
in multiple systems.
Nothing in here is something that hasn't been reused.
So yeah, the next step is building in Linking,
which is boring.
But it's worth noting that Solidity has no namespace.
And this is kind of a smell that our contract systems haven't
really gotten that complicated yet.
Maker Core, for example, has four different deployed DAPs
as versions.
And being able to reproduce and compile
without having like type name collisions
requires us to have a custom linker.
So we're going to maintain that until Solidity gets namespaces.
So after you've written some contracts
and you've built them, you obviously want to test them.
And our perspective on this is that the primary consumer
of contracts is other contracts.
And so we emphasize writing your test to Solidity,
pretending your other contracts are communicating with it.
And for this, we have a magic test contract
where it has an associated harness that
understands how to interpret the functions defined on it.
So this is our first example of chain forking.
So this is an example test.
If you've used any unit testing for American other languages,
this should be familiar.
Setup gets called every time.
And then if you have multiple test functions,
they each get called in isolation.
So our first example of using chain forking
is this is, suppose we did a DAPL chain new,
and we specified the internal VM, which
means like a brand new fresh EVM.
Then we deploy our contract to it, call setup,
and then concurrently we can fork it
and run each test independently.
So that's nice.
But we really want to--
so like part of the value of DAPL
is that we can take these dependent systems
and make a very accurate mock of them.
And we preserve all the type of information.
You can be very certain that the behavior will be similar
on the live chain and on your fake local chain.
But you might as well just use the real thing.
I mean, it's even better.
So in this example, basically you write a test,
and you assume that the contract is running in the context
of an existing chain.
But you can do more stuff with it in your private context
that lets you test a few more features.
So to give a concrete example of this,
if you run this in the modern context, this will work.
But if you run this on a private internal chain,
this won't work, unless you burn some ether first.
So I should have written the usage behind this.
But basically what happens is first you enter the modern context,
and then you do DAPL test on this contract.
And the result is that it works.
This address 0 refers to address 0 on Morden.
And so when you assert that the burned balance is more than 0,
it's true.
All right, so testing is kind of interesting.
But it gets really interesting when
we want to deploy contracts, which
is one of the applications of what we called wallet-side scripting,
which is another magic EVM contract.
But its harness has hijacked the create and call
off codes and makes what usually when you have create a call,
it creates a message call, it's like internal to one transaction.
But instead what we do is actually create a full transaction
and then block the wallet-side EVM execution
until it gets confirmed.
And you combine this with the chain-forking feature.
What you can do is simulate live deployments
before you actually do them, do dry runs.
And then you can run consistency checks
on the result of your system.
Make sure that your update that you
want to do doesn't screw anything up.
So here's a real world example of why we might want to do this.
You're on Slack and you get a message from me that says,
hey, please confirm proposal 66.
It is a critical bug fix.
It's going to swap out some of the contracts.
That's ones that don't have this bug.
So if you're a responsible administrator
of multi-sick holder of whatever system you're running,
you will, of course, do a mock chain fork
and run this transaction and simulate environment
to make sure that it still passes whatever consistency checks
you guys have defined.
In our case, let me show you the example.
So this is why this type information--
preserving this type information in the Dev Vault
is so powerful is that then we can hoist it
into the wallet site scripting environment
and have the full type system there with all the type
information you need to make sure that this--
what you're doing makes sense.
There's actually a token defined in the environment.
It's actually typed as a token.
It has a confirmed function.
Blah, blah, blah.
And so in this case, what we're doing
is we're confirming it's from our address,
but then we're pretending to set the origin
to a different address, which is one of the magic features
of the script contract, so that the origin is mocked.
Then we do a confirmation from that origin.
And then we-- so in this example, the confirm also
does the trigger, so the update runs.
And then we do a consistency check.
And in this example, you can see, oh,
our made-up consistency check failed.
So you know that this wasn't actually me.
This was some hacker that is trying
to run a bad update on the system.
But each multi-signmember can easily independently verify
what the resulting state of actually running
those transactions are.
All right.
And then the final step is publish your dot file,
get other people to import your code and have some code
reuse, because there's so much duplication of effort
going on in the ecosystem right now,
and it's partially because it's just so hard to reuse
other people's code.
So I'm going to very quickly give very small sneak peek
about what are some other things that are coming.
Basically, all the things I described
could be done in a GUI.
So you could do your own the DAO hack
through a clicky UI if you want to.
And then some more things that we have in the pipeline
are better, more wallet-side EVM extension features.
So one thing is having one of the addresses
be like a hard-coded contract, which is a thin client.
And so this is called DIY sharding.
Basically, if you have two private chains,
you can make up your own interval auction communication
scheme very easily if you have the thin clients
for the other chain as an EVM extension
or like a hard-coded contract.
Likewise, creating a mint opcode
would allow you to write your private chain's consensus
mechanism in the EVM.
And finally, system calls allow you
to bridge the old world web with the new world
thin proofs for everything.
And you can have a dedicated side chain that say does SMS relay.
This is the example we have.
So it does SMS.send, but it might
in the side this function emits an event.
And this is like a proof that this company claimed
that they sent an SMS at this time in response
to some action that you did.
And so this is the general direction we're moving towards.
And so that's actually all I have to talk about.
Thank you for listening.
Let's go to lunch.
[APPLAUSE]
[MUSIC PLAYING]
Thank you.
